prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Due to the large CO(2-1) line width measured with APEX (770kms-1), we need to select the FDM largest bandwidth spectral window as possible (1.87GHz ~ 2500kms-1). This can be done at the expenses of spectral resolution (we require here 1.5 kms-1). While the sensitivity computation is based on a much poorer velocity resolution (75kms-1, ie ten points across the line width), we aim at investigating the molecular gas kinematics at a much finer resolution in case of a favourable detection scenario. We set the spectral averaging to 2 to meet as much as possible the data rate requirements. We placed three other spectral windows in TDM mode. This will be used for robust phase calibration, and possibly to detect continuum emission.

We expect that the maximum extent of the CO will be (2x1) sq. kpc, thus implying a request in LAS of ~4 arcsec, at the source redshift. We aim at sampling the molecular gas at a 200 pc scale, i.e. ~ 0.4arcsec resolution. This implies ~50 synthesized beams across the emission region.

We estimated the CO (2-1) peak line flux density per beam by assuming that the APEX CO(2-1) integrated flux (3.83 K kms-1 in a 27arcsec beamsize) is uniformly distributed over a region of 2 kpc x 1 kpc (ie 4x2 arcsec2 at the source redhsift). At the requested angular (0.4 arcsec) and spectral (75kms-1, ie 10 independent points across the line width) resolutions, and considering a SN~10, this calls for a request of a sensitivity of 400 muJy/beam.

Due to the large CO(2-1) line width measured with APEX (774kms-1), we need to select the FDM largest bandwidth spectral window as possible (1.87GHz ~ 2500kms-1). This can be done at the expenses of spectral resolution (we require here 1.5 kms-1). While the sensitivity computation is based on a much poorer velocity resolution (75kms-1, ie ten points across the line width), we aim at investigating the molecular gas kinematics at a much finer resolution in case of a favourable detection scenario. We set the spectral averaging to 2 to meet as much as possible the data rate requirements. We placed three other spectral windows in TDM mode. This will be used for robust phase calibration, and possibly to detect continuum emission.

We expect that the maximum extent of the CO will be (2x1) sq. kpc, thus implying a request in LAS of ~3.3 arcsec, at the source redshift. We aim at sampling the molecular gas at a 200 pc scale, i.e. ~ 0.3arcsec resolution. This implies ~50 synthesized beams across the emission region.

We estimated the CO (2-1) peak line flux density per beam by assuming that the APEX CO(2-1) integrated flux (7.19 K kms-1 in a 27arcsec beamsize) is uniformly distributed over a region of 2 kpc x 1 kpc (ie 3.3x1.75 arcsec2 at the source redhsift). At the requested angular (0.3 arcsec) and spectral (75kms-1, ie 10 independent points across the line width) resolutions, and considering a SN~10, this calls for a request of a sensitivity of 800 muJy/beam.
We are not aiming at a detection of the continuum emission. The expected value @230GHz has been extrapolated from the IRAS 100mum flux density (5.3Jy), computed assuming a modified black body model for continuum dust emission at ~50K.

Due to the large CO(2-1) line width measured with APEX (334kms-1), we need to select the FDM largest bandwidth spectral window as possible (1.87GHz ~ 2500kms-1). This can be done at the expenses of spectral resolution (we require here 1.5 kms-1). While the sensitivity computation is based on a much poorer velocity resolution (30kms-1, ie ten points across the line width), we aim at investigating the molecular gas kinematics at a much finer resolution in case of a favourable detection scenario. We set the spectral averaging to 2 to meet as much as possible the data rate requirements. We placed three other spectral windows in TDM mode. This will be used for robust phase calibration, and possibly to detect continuum emission.

We expect that the maximum extent of the CO will be (2x1) sq. kpc, thus implying a request in LAS of ~3.5 arcsec, at the source redshift. We aim at sampling the molecular gas at a 300 pc scale, i.e. ~ 0.54arcsec resolution. This implies ~20 synthesized beams across the emission region.

We estimated the CO (2-1) peak line flux density per beam by assuming that the APEX CO(2-1) integrated flux (0.5 K kms-1 in a 27arcsec beamsize) is uniformly distributed over a region of 2 kpc x 1 kpc (ie 3.5x1.75 arcsec2 at the source redhsift). At the requested angular (0.54 arcsec) and spectral (30kms-1, ie 10 independent points across the line width) resolutions, and considering a SN~10, this calls for a request of a sensitivity of 270 muJy/beam.

Due to the large CO(2-1) line width measured with APEX (446kms-1), we need to select the FDM largest bandwidth spectral window as possible (1.87GHz ~ 2500kms-1). This can be done at the expenses of spectral resolution (we require here 1.5 kms-1). While the sensitivity computation is based on a much poorer velocity resolution (45kms-1, ie ten points across the line width), we aim at investigating the molecular gas kinematics at a much finer resolution in case of a favourable detection scenario. We set the spectral averaging to 2 to meet as much as possible the data rate requirements. We placed three other spectral windows in TDM mode. This will be used for robust phase calibration, and possibly to detect continuum emission.

We expect that the maximum extent of the CO will be (2x1) sq. kpc, thus implying a request in LAS of ~10 arcsec, at the source redshift. We aim at sampling the molecular gas at a 200 pc scale, i.e. ~1.0 arcsec resolution. This implies ~50 synthesized beams across the emission region.

We estimated the CO (2-1) peak line flux density per beam by assuming that the APEX CO(2-1) integrated flux (1.68 K kms-1 in a 27arcsec beamsize) is uniformly distributed over a region of 2 kpc x 1 kpc (ie 10x5 arcsec2 at the source redhsift). At the requested angular (1.0 arcsec) and spectral (45kms-1, ie 10 independent points across the line width) resolutions, and considering a SN~10, this calls for a request of a sensitivity of 330 muJy/beam.
We are not aiming at a detection of the continuum emission. The expected value @230GHz has been extrapolated from the IRAS 100mum flux density (1.0Jy), computed assuming a modified black body model for continuum dust emission at ~50K.

Due to the large CO(2-1) line width measured with APEX (785kms-1), we need to select the FDM largest bandwidth spectral window as possible (1.87GHz ~ 2500kms-1). This can be done at the expenses of spectral resolution (we require here 1.5 kms-1). While the sensitivity computation is based on a much poorer velocity resolution (75kms-1, ie ten points across the line width), we aim at investigating the molecular gas kinematics at a much finer resolution in case of a favourable detection scenario. We set the spectral averaging to 2 to meet as much as possible the data rate requirements. We placed three other spectral windows in TDM mode. This will be used for robust phase calibration, and possibly to detect continuum emission.

We expect that the maximum extent of the CO will be (2x1) sq. kpc, thus implying a request in LAS of ~5.6 arcsec, at the source redshift. We aim at sampling the molecular gas at a 200 pc scale, i.e. ~ 0.56 arcsec resolution. This implies ~50 synthesized beams across the emission region.

We estimated the CO (2-1) peak line flux density per beam by assuming that the APEX CO(2-1) integrated flux (2.39 K kms-1 in a 27arcsec beamsize) is uniformly distributed over a region of 2 kpc x 1 kpc (ie 5.6x2.8 arcsec2 at the source redhsift). At the requested angular (0.56 arcsec) and spectral (75kms-1, ie 10 independent points across the line width) resolutions, and considering a SN~10, this calls for a request of a sensitivity of 280 muJy/beam.

Due to the large CO(2-1) line width measured with APEX (864kms-1), we need to select the FDM largest bandwidth spectral window as possible (1.87GHz ~ 2500kms-1). This can be done at the expenses of spectral resolution (we require here 1.5 kms-1). While the sensitivity computation is based on a much poorer velocity resolution (85kms-1, ie ten points across the line width), we aim at investigating the molecular gas kinematics at a much finer resolution in case of a favourable detection scenario. We set the spectral averaging to 2 to meet as much as possible the data rate requirements. We placed three other spectral windows in TDM mode. This will be used for robust phase calibration, and possibly to detect continuum emission.

We expect that the maximum extent of the CO will be on a 3.5x2 arcsec2 scale, thus implying a request in LAS of ~3.5 arcsec. We aim at sampling the molecular gas at a 100 pc scale, i.e. ~ 0.4arcsec resolution. This implies ~50 synthesized beams across the emission region.

We estimated the CO (2-1) peak line flux density per beam by assuming that the APEX CO(2-1) integrated flux (1.5 K kms-1 in a 27arcsec beamsize) is uniformly distributed over a 3.5x2 arcsec2 region (or 1.4x0.8 sq. kpc), which corresponds to the size of the dust disk seen in absorption by HST (Lauer et al. 2005).
At the requested angular (0.4 arcsec) and spectral (85kms-1, ie 10 independent points across the line width) resolutions, and considering a SN~10, this calls for a request of a sensitivity of 180 muJy/beam.
We are not aiming at a detection of the continuum emission. The expected value @230GHz has been extrapolated from the IRAS 100mum flux density (0.3Jy), computed assuming a modified black body model for continuum dust emission at ~50K.

Due to the large CO(2-1) line width measured with APEX (650kms-1), we need to select the FDM largest bandwidth spectral window as possible (1.87GHz ~ 2500kms-1). This can be done at the expenses of spectral resolution (we require here 1.5 kms-1). While the sensitivity computation is based on a much poorer velocity resolution (65kms-1, ie ten points across the line width), we aim at investigating the molecular gas kinematics at a much finer resolution in case of a favourable detection scenario. We set the spectral averaging to 2 to meet as much as possible the data rate requirements. We placed three other spectral windows in TDM mode. This will be used for robust phase calibration, and possibly to detect continuum emission.

We expect that the maximum extent of the CO will be (2x1) sq. kpc, thus implying a request in LAS of ~5.5 arcsec, at the source redshift. We aim at sampling the molecular gas at a 200 pc scale, i.e. ~ 0.4arcsec resolution. This implies ~50 synthesized beams across the emission region.

We estimated the CO (2-1) peak line flux density per beam by assuming that the APEX CO(2-1) integrated flux (2.2 K kms-1 in a 27arcsec beamsize) is uniformly distributed over a region of 2 kpc x 1 kpc (ie 5.5x2.8 arcsec2 at the source redhsift). At the requested angular (0.55 arcsec) and spectral (65kms-1, ie 10 independent points across the line width) resolutions, and considering a SN~10, this calls for a request of a sensitivity of 300 muJy/beam.
We are not aiming at a detection of the continuum emission. The expected value @230GHz has been extrapolated from the IRAS 100mum flux density (1.3Jy), computed assuming a modified black body model for continuum dust emission at ~50K.

Due to the large CO(2-1) line width measured with APEX (492kms-1), we need to select the FDM largest bandwidth spectral window as possible (1.87GHz ~ 2500kms-1). This can be done at the expenses of spectral resolution (we require here 1.5 kms-1). While the sensitivity computation is based on a much poorer velocity resolution (45kms-1, ie ten points across the line width), we aim at investigating the molecular gas kinematics at a much finer resolution in case of a favourable detection scenario. We set the spectral averaging to 2 to meet as much as possible the data rate requirements. We placed three other spectral windows in TDM mode. This will be used for robust phase calibration, and possibly to detect continuum emission.

We expect that the maximum extent of the CO will be (3.5x2) arcsec2, thus implying a request in LAS of ~3.5 arcsec, at the source redshift. We aim at sampling the molecular gas at a 100 pc scale, i.e. ~ 0.8arcsec resolution. This implies ~10 synthesized beams across the emission region.

We estimated the CO (2-1) peak line flux density per beam by assuming that the APEX CO(2-1) integrated flux (0.7 K kms-1 in a 27arcsec beamsize) is uniformly distributed over a 3.5x2 arcsec2 region (or 500x300 sq. pc), which corresponds to the size of the dust disk seen in absorption by HST (Lauer et al. 2005).
At the requested angular (0.8 arcsec) and spectral (45kms-1, ie 10 independent points across the line width) resolutions, and considering a SN~10, this calls for a request of a sensitivity of 520 muJy/beam.
We are not aiming at a detection of the continuum emission. The expected value @230GHz has been extrapolated from the IRAS 100mum flux density (1.1Jy), computed assuming a modified black body model for continuum dust emission at ~50K.

Due to the large CO(2-1) line width measured with APEX (250kms-1), we need to select the FDM largest bandwidth spectral window as possible (1.87GHz ~ 2500kms-1). This can be done at the expenses of spectral resolution (we require here 1.5 kms-1). While the sensitivity computation is based on a much poorer velocity resolution (25kms-1, ie ten points across the line width), we aim at investigating the molecular gas kinematics at a much finer resolution in case of a favourable detection scenario. We set the spectral averaging to 2 to meet as much as possible the data rate requirements. We placed three other spectral windows in TDM mode. This will be used for robust phase calibration, and possibly to detect continuum emission.

We expect that the maximum extent of the CO will be (3.5x2) arcsec2, thus implying a request in LAS of ~3.5 arcsec, at the source redshift. We aim at sampling the molecular gas at a 100 pc scale, i.e. ~ 0.4arcsec resolution. This implies ~40 synthesized beams across the emission region.

We estimated the CO (2-1) peak line flux density per beam by assuming that the APEX CO(2-1) integrated flux (1.52 K kms-1 in a 27arcsec beamsize) is uniformly distributed over a 3.5x2 arcsec2 region (or 700x400 sq. pc), which corresponds to the size of the dust disk seen in absorption by HST (Lauer et al. 2005).
At the requested angular (0.4 arcsec) and spectral (25kms-1, ie 10 independent points across the line width) resolutions, and considering a SN~10, this calls for a request of a sensitivity of 500 muJy/beam.
We are not aiming at a detection of the continuum emission. The expected value @230GHz has been extrapolated from the IRAS 100mum flux density (0.75Jy), computed assuming a modified black body model for continuum dust emission at ~50K.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Galaxy formation theories struggle to explain the quenching of star formation and the formation of sub-structures in early-type galaxies (ETG). The solutions to both problems may well be connected: molecular gas can feed active galactic nuclei and generate feedback, while also leading to new decoupled stellar components. We have already obtained VLT/VIMOS integral-field unit spectroscopy and 12CO(2-1) line observations with APEX for a complete volume-limited (z<0.03) sample of 10 southern radio galaxies. Here, we request follow-up CO(2-1) imaging of the 9 objects rich in molecular gas. Our targets differ from ETGs studied previously at similar spatial resolution (100-300 pc), being significantly more massive and harbouring active jets. We will thus be able to isolate the role played by jets (likely the dominant feedback mode in local ETGs) in the overall formation and evolution of ETGs. ALMA is essential and ideal for the proposed mapping and, using Atlas3D as a radio-quiet control sample, our sample is appropriately sized for a first study aiming to identify and contrast trends.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Radioastronomy of Bologna, INAF
